<!--[if lt IE 7]><style type="text/css">body{behavior:url("/w/skins/vector/csshover.min.htc")}</style><![endif]--></head>
<body class="mediawiki ltr sitedir-ltr ns-0 ns-subject page-Chickpea skin-vector action-view vector-animateLayout">
		<div id="mw-page-base" class="noprint"></div>
		<div id="mw-head-base" class="noprint"></div>
		<div id="content" class="mw-body" role="main">
			<a id="top"></a>
			<div id="mw-js-message" style="display:none;"></div>
						<h1 id="firstHeading" class="firstHeading" lang="en"><span dir="auto">Chickpea</span></h1>
			<div id="bodyContent">
								<div id="siteSub">From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia</div>
								<div id="contentSub"></div>
												<div id="jump-to-nav" class="mw-jump">
					Jump to:					<a href="#mw-navigation">navigation</a>, 					<a href="#p-search">search</a>
				</div>
				<div id="mw-content-text" lang="en" dir="ltr" class="mw-content-ltr"><div><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Taxobox/core&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Taxobox/core (page does not exist)">Template:Taxobox/core</a></div>
<p>The <b>chickpea</b> (<i><b>Cicer arietinum</b></i>) is a <a href="/wiki/Legume" title="Legume">legume</a> of the family <a href="/wiki/Fabaceae" title="Fabaceae">Fabaceae</a>, subfamily <a href="/wiki/Faboideae" title="Faboideae">Faboideae</a>. Its seeds are high in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Protein_(nutrient)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Protein (nutrient) (page does not exist)">protein</a>. It is one of the earliest cultivated legumes: 7,500-year-old remains have been found in the <a href="/wiki/Middle_East" title="Middle East">Middle East</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-1">[1]</a></sup>
</p><p>Other common names for the species include <b>garbanzo bean</b>, <b>ceci bean</b>, <b>channa</b> and <b>Bengal gram</b>.
</p>
<div id="toc" class="toc"><div id="toctitle"><h2>Contents</h2></div>
<ul>

<ul>

</ul>
</li>

<ul>

</ul>
</li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-9"><a href="#Production"><span class="tocnumber">5</span> <span class="toctext">Production</span></a></li>

<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-13"><a href="#External_links"><span class="tocnumber">9</span> <span class="toctext">External links</span></a></li>
</ul>
</div>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Etymology">Etymology</span></h2>
<p>The name "chickpea" traces back through the <a href="/wiki/French_language" title="French language">French</a> <i><span lang="fr">chiche</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Category_handler&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Category handler (page does not exist)">Template:Category handler</a></i> to <i><span lang="la"><a href="/wiki/Cicer" title="Cicer">cicer</a></span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Category_handler&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Category handler (page does not exist)">Template:Category handler</a></i>, <a href="/wiki/Latin_language" title="Latin language" class="mw-redirect">Latin</a> for ‘chickpea’ (from which the Roman <a href="/wiki/Cognomen" title="Cognomen">cognomen</a> <a href="/wiki/Cicero" title="Cicero">Cicero</a> was taken). The <i><a href="/wiki/Oxford_English_Dictionary" title="Oxford English Dictionary">Oxford English Dictionary</a></i> lists a 1548 citation that reads, "<i>Cicer</i> may be named in English Cich, or ciche pease, after the Frenche tongue." The dictionary cites "Chick-pea" in the mid-18th century; the original word in English taken directly from French was <i>chich</i>, found in print in English in 1388.
</p><p>The word <i><span lang="osp">garbanzo</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Category_handler&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Category handler (page does not exist)">Template:Category handler</a></i> came to English as "calavance" in the 17th century, from Old <a href="/wiki/Spanish_language" title="Spanish language">Spanish</a> (perhaps influenced by Old Spanish <i><span lang="osp">garroba</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Category_handler&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Category handler (page does not exist)">Template:Category handler</a></i> or <i><span lang="osp">algarroba</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Category_handler&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Category handler (page does not exist)">Template:Category handler</a></i>), though it came to refer to a variety of other beans (<i>cf.</i> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Hyacinth_bean&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Hyacinth bean (page does not exist)">Calavance</a>). This word is still in use in Latin America and Spain to designate chickpeas. The Portuguese (?) <i><span lang="pt">arvanço</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Category_handler&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Category handler (page does not exist)">Template:Category handler</a></i> has suggested to some that the origin of the word <i>garbanzo</i> is in the Greek <i><span lang="el">erebinthos</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Category_handler&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Category handler (page does not exist)">Template:Category handler</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2">[2]</a></sup> But the <i>Oxford English Dictionary</i> notes that some scholars doubt this; it also mentions a possible origination in the word <i><span lang="eu">garbantzu</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Category_handler&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Category handler (page does not exist)">Template:Category handler</a></i>, from <a href="/wiki/Basque_language" title="Basque language">Basque</a> — a non-<a href="/w/index.php?title=Indo-European&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Indo-European (page does not exist)">Indo-European</a> tongue, believed to be one of the oldest languages in Europe — in which it is a compound of <i><span lang="eu">garau</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Category_handler&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Category handler (page does not exist)">Template:Category handler</a></i>, seed + <i><span lang="eu">antzu</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Category_handler&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Category handler (page does not exist)">Template:Category handler</a></i>, dry.
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Potaje_de_garbanzos_y_collejas5.JPG" title="File:Potaje de garbanzos y collejas5.JPG">File:Potaje de garbanzos y collejas5.JPG</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/w/index.php?title=Manchego_cuisine&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Manchego cuisine (page does not exist)">Manchego cuisine</a>; chickpea and <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Silene_vulgaris&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Silene vulgaris (page does not exist)">Silene vulgaris</a></i> stew. <i>(Potaje de garbanzos y collejas)</i></div></div></div>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="History">History</span></h2>
<p><a href="/wiki/Neolithic_founder_crops" title="Neolithic founder crops">Domesticated</a> chickpeas have been found in the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Aceramic&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Aceramic (page does not exist)">aceramic</a> levels of <a href="/wiki/Jericho" title="Jericho">Jericho</a> (<a href="/wiki/Pre-Pottery_Neolithic_B" title="Pre-Pottery Neolithic B">PPNB</a>) along with <a href="/w/index.php?title=Cay%C3%B6n%C3%BC&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Cayönü (page does not exist)">Cayönü</a> in Turkey and in <a href="/wiki/Neolithic" title="Neolithic">Neolithic</a> pottery at Hacilar, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Turkey&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Turkey (page does not exist)">Turkey</a>. They were found in the late Neolithic (about 3500 BCE) at <a href="/wiki/Thessaly" title="Thessaly">Thessaly</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Kastanas&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Kastanas (page does not exist)">Kastanas</a>, <a href="/wiki/Lerna" title="Lerna">Lerna</a> and <a href="/wiki/Dimini" title="Dimini">Dimini</a>, <a href="/wiki/Greece" title="Greece">Greece</a>. In southern France <a href="/wiki/Mesolithic" title="Mesolithic">Mesolithic</a> layers in a cave at L'Abeurador, <a href="/wiki/Aude" title="Aude">Aude</a> have yielded wild chickpeas <a href="/wiki/Radiocarbon_dating" title="Radiocarbon dating">carbon dated</a> to 6790±90 BCE.<sup id="cite_ref-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-3">[3]</a></sup>
</p><p>By the <a href="/wiki/Bronze_Age" title="Bronze Age">Bronze Age</a>, chickpeas were known in <a href="/wiki/Italy" title="Italy">Italy</a> and <a href="/wiki/Greece" title="Greece">Greece</a>. In classical Greece, they were called <i><span lang="el">erébinthos</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Category_handler&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Category handler (page does not exist)">Template:Category handler</a></i> and eaten as a staple, a dessert, or consumed raw when young. The Romans knew several varieties such as venus, ram, and punic chickpeas. They were both cooked down into a <a href="/wiki/Broth" title="Broth">broth</a> and roasted as a snack. The Roman gourmet <a href="/wiki/Apicius" title="Apicius">Apicius</a> gives several recipes for chickpeas. Carbonized chickpeas have been found at the Roman legion fort at <a href="/wiki/Neuss" title="Neuss">Neuss</a> (Novaesium), <a href="/wiki/Germany" title="Germany">Germany</a> in layers from the first century CE, along with rice.{{ safesubst:#invoke:Unsubst||$N=Citation needed |date=__DATE__ |$B=
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Fix&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Fix (page does not exist)">Template:Fix</a>
}}
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Chakhchoukha9.JPG" title="File:Chakhchoukha9.JPG">File:Chakhchoukha9.JPG</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/w/index.php?title=Chakhchoukha&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Chakhchoukha (page does not exist)">Chakhchoukha</a> in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Algerian_cuisine&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Algerian cuisine (page does not exist)">Algerian cuisine</a>; freshly cooked <i>Marqa</i> before mixing with <i>Rougag</i></div></div></div>
<p>Chickpeas are mentioned in <a href="/wiki/Charlemagne" title="Charlemagne">Charlemagne</a>'s <i><span lang="la">Capitulare de villis</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Category_handler&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Category handler (page does not exist)">Template:Category handler</a></i> (about 800 CE) as <i><span lang="la">cicer italicum</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Category_handler&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Category handler (page does not exist)">Template:Category handler</a></i>, as grown in each <a href="/wiki/Manorialism" title="Manorialism">imperial demesne</a>. <a href="/wiki/Albertus_Magnus" title="Albertus Magnus">Albertus Magnus</a> mentions red, white and black varieties. <a href="/wiki/Nicholas_Culpeper" title="Nicholas Culpeper">Nicholas Culpeper</a> noted "chick-pease or cicers" are less "<a href="/wiki/Flatulence" title="Flatulence">windy</a>" than peas and more nourishing. Ancient people also associated chickpeas with <a href="/wiki/Medical_astrology" title="Medical astrology">Venus</a> because they were said to offer medical uses such as increasing sperm and milk, provoking menstruation and urine and helping to treat <a href="/wiki/Kidney_stone" title="Kidney stone">kidney stones</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Culpeper_4-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Culpeper-4">[4]</a></sup> "White cicers" were thought to be especially strong and helpful.<sup id="cite_ref-Culpeper_4-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Culpeper-4">[4]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Chholay.JPG" title="File:Chholay.JPG">File:Chholay.JPG</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Green chickpea</div></div></div>
<p>In 1793, ground-roast chickpeas were noted by a German writer as a substitute for <a href="/wiki/Coffee" title="Coffee">coffee</a> in Europe. In the <a href="/w/index.php?title=World_War_I&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="World War I (page does not exist)">First World War</a>, they were grown for this use in some areas of Germany. They are still sometimes brewed instead of coffee.<sup id="cite_ref-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-5">[5]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-6">[6]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Sequencing_the_chickpea_genome">Sequencing the chickpea genome</span></h3>
<p>Sequencing of the chickpea genome has been completed for 90 chickpea genotypes, including several wild species. A collaboration of 20 research organizations, led by <a href="/wiki/ICRISAT" title="ICRISAT" class="mw-redirect">ICRISAT</a> identified more than 28,000 genes and several million genetic markers. Scientists expect this work will lead to the development of superior varieties. The new research will benefit the millions of developing country farmers who grow chickpea as a source of much needed income, as well as for its ability to add nitrogen to the soil in which it grows. Production is growing rapidly across the developing world, especially in <a href="/wiki/West_Asia" title="West Asia" class="mw-redirect">West Asia</a> where production has grown four-fold over the past 30 years. <a href="/wiki/India" title="India">India</a> is by far the world largest producer but is also the largest importer.<sup id="cite_ref-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-7">[7]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Description">Description</span></h2>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Chickpea_pods.jpg" title="File:Chickpea pods.jpg">File:Chickpea pods.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Chickpea pods.</div></div></div>
<p>The plant grows to between 20–50&#160;cm (8–20&#160;inches) high and has small feathery leaves on either side of the stem. Chickpeas are a type of <a href="/wiki/Pulse_(legume)" title="Pulse (legume)">pulse</a>, with one seedpod containing two or three peas. It has white flowers with blue, violet or pink veins. Chickpeas need a subtropical or tropical climate with more than <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> of annual rain.{{ safesubst:#invoke:Unsubst||$N=Citation needed |date=__DATE__ |$B=
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Fix&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Fix (page does not exist)">Template:Fix</a>
}} They can be grown in a temperate climate but yields will be much lower.{{ safesubst:#invoke:Unsubst||$N=Citation needed |date=__DATE__ |$B=
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Fix&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Fix (page does not exist)">Template:Fix</a>
}}
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Types">Types</span></h3>
<p>There are two main kinds of chickpea:
</p>
<ul>
<li> Desi, which has small, darker seeds and a rough coat, cultivated mostly in the <a href="/wiki/India" title="India">India</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bangladesh" title="Bangladesh">Bangladesh</a>, parts of <a href="/wiki/Pakistan" title="Pakistan">Pakistan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ethiopia" title="Ethiopia">Ethiopia</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mexico&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Mexico (page does not exist)">Mexico</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Iran" title="Iran">Iran</a>.
</li>
<li> Kabuli, which has lighter coloured, larger seeds and a smoother coat, mainly grown in Southern Europe, Northern Africa, <a href="/wiki/Afghanistan" title="Afghanistan">Afghanistan</a>, <a href="/wiki/India" title="India">India</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pakistan" title="Pakistan">Pakistan</a> and <a href="/wiki/Chile" title="Chile">Chile</a>, also introduced during the 18th century to India.<sup id="cite_ref-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-8">[8]</a></sup>
</li>
</ul>
<p>The <i>Desi</i> (meaning 'country' or 'local' in <a href="/wiki/Hindi" title="Hindi">Hindi</a>) is also known as Bengal gram or kala chana (black chickpea in both <a href="/wiki/Hindi" title="Hindi">Hindi</a> and <a href="/wiki/Urdu" title="Urdu">Urdu</a>) or chhola boot. <i>Kabuli</i> (meaning 'from <a href="/wiki/Kabul" title="Kabul">Kabul</a>' in Hindi, since they were thought to have come from Afghanistan when first seen in India) or <i>safed chana</i> is the kind widely grown throughout the Mediterranean, <a href="/wiki/India" title="India">India</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pakistan" title="Pakistan">Pakistan</a> and <a href="/wiki/Afghanistan" title="Afghanistan">Afghanistan</a>. <i>Desi</i> is likely the earliest form since it closely resembles seeds found both on archaeological sites and the wild plant ancestor (<i>Cicer reticulatum</i>) of domesticated chickpeas, which only grows in southeast Turkey, where it is believed to have originated. <i>Desi</i> chickpeas have a markedly higher fiber content than Kabulis and hence a very low <a href="/wiki/Glycemic_index" title="Glycemic index">glycemic index</a> which may make them suitable for people with blood sugar problems.<sup id="cite_ref-9" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-9">[9]</a></sup> The desi type is used to make Chana Dal, which is a split chickpea with the skin removed.
</p><p>An uncommon black chickpea "ceci neri" is grown only in Puglia, Italy.  These chickpeas are larger and blacker than the desi "kala chana" variety.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Uses">Uses</span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Human_food">Human food</span></h3>
<p>Mature chickpeas can be cooked and eaten cold in <a href="/wiki/Salad" title="Salad">salads</a>, cooked in <a href="/wiki/Stew" title="Stew">stews</a>, ground into a flour called <a href="/wiki/Gram_flour" title="Gram flour">gram flour</a> (also known as chickpea flour and <i><a href="/wiki/Gram_flour" title="Gram flour">besan</a></i> and used frequently in <a href="/wiki/Indian_cuisine" title="Indian cuisine">Indian cuisine</a>), ground and shaped in balls and fried as <a href="/wiki/Falafel" title="Falafel">falafel</a>, stirred into a batter and baked to make <a href="/wiki/Farinata" title="Farinata">farinata</a> or <a href="/w/index.php?title=Panelle&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Panelle (page does not exist)">panelle</a>.
</p><p>In the <a href="/wiki/Iberian_Peninsula" title="Iberian Peninsula">Iberian Peninsula</a>, chickpeas are very popular: In <a href="/wiki/Portugal" title="Portugal">Portugal</a> they are often used in hot dishes with <a href="/wiki/Bacalhau" title="Bacalhau">bacalhau</a> and in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Soup&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Soup (page does not exist)">soup</a>. In Spain they are often used cold in different <a href="/wiki/Tapas" title="Tapas">tapas</a> and salads, as well as in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Cocido_madrile%C3%B1o&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Cocido madrileño (page does not exist)">cocido madrileño</a>. In <a href="/w/index.php?title=Egypt&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Egypt (page does not exist)">Egypt</a>, chickpeas are used as a topping for <a href="/wiki/Kushari" title="Kushari">Kushari</a>.
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Hummus_from_The_Nile.jpg" title="File:Hummus from The Nile.jpg">File:Hummus from The Nile.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/Hummus" title="Hummus">Hummus</a> with olive oil</div></div></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Hummus" title="Hummus">Hummus</a> is the Arabic word for chickpeas, which are often cooked and ground into a paste and mixed with <i>tahini</i>, sesame seed paste, the blend called <i><a href="/wiki/Hummus" title="Hummus">hummus bi tahini</a></i>, or chickpeas are roasted, spiced, and eaten as a snack, such as <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Leblebi&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Leblebi (page does not exist)">leblebi</a></i>. By the end of the 20th century, hummus had emerged as part of the American culinary fabric.<sup id="cite_ref-marks_10-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-marks-10">[10]</a></sup> By 2010, 5% of Americans consumed hummus on a regular basis,<sup id="cite_ref-marks_10-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-marks-10">[10]</a></sup> and it was present in 17% of American households.<sup id="cite_ref-fox_11-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-fox-11">[11]</a></sup>
</p><p>Some varieties of chickpeas can be popped and eaten like popcorn.<sup id="cite_ref-12" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-12">[12]</a></sup>
</p><p>Chickpeas and Bengal grams are used to make curries and are one of the most popular vegetarian foods in <a href="/wiki/India" title="India">India</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pakistan" title="Pakistan">Pakistan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bangladesh" title="Bangladesh">Bangladesh</a> and the <a href="/wiki/UK" title="UK" class="mw-redirect">UK</a>. On the Indian subcontinent, green chickpeas are called <i>Chana</i> (ચણા) in <a href="/wiki/Gujarati_language" title="Gujarati language">Gujarati</a> <i>Harbharaa</i> in <a href="/wiki/Marathi_language" title="Marathi language">Marathi</a>, while other varieties are known as <i>Kadale Kaalu</i> in <a href="/wiki/Kannada_language" title="Kannada language">Kannada</a>, <i>Chanagalu</i> (చనగలు) in <a href="/wiki/Telugu_language" title="Telugu language">Telugu</a>, <i>chana</i> in <a href="/wiki/Hindi" title="Hindi">Hindi</a> and other related languages, small brown peas are called Chhola and the whitish bigger variety is called <i>Kabuli Chhola</i> in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Bengali_language&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Bengali language (page does not exist)">Bengali</a> and <i>Konda Kadalai</i> in <a href="/wiki/Tamil_language" title="Tamil language">Tamil</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-13" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-13">[13]</a></sup> where they are a major source of protein in a mostly vegetarian culture. Typically Chana in Hindi and Punjabi might refer to both varieties, as might chhole, but the former is more the green hard small variety while the latter is the large creamy softer one and also the more popular dish served around the region at home and at celebrations.
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Choleindia.jpg" title="File:Choleindia.jpg">File:Choleindia.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/w/index.php?title=Chana_masala&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Chana masala (page does not exist)">Chana masala</a>, a popular dish from <a href="/w/index.php?title=Punjab&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Punjab (page does not exist)">Punjab</a>, India</div></div></div>
<p>Many popular dishes in <a href="/wiki/Indian_cuisine" title="Indian cuisine">Indian cuisine</a> are made with chickpea flour, such as <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Mirchi_Bajji&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Mirchi Bajji (page does not exist)">Mirchi Bajji</a></i> and <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Mirapakaya&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Mirapakaya (page does not exist)">Mirapakaya</a> bajji <a href="/wiki/Telugu_language" title="Telugu language">Telugu</a></i>. In India, as well as in the <a href="/wiki/Levant" title="Levant">Levant</a>, unripe chickpeas are often picked out of the pod and eaten as a raw snack and the leaves are eaten as a <a href="/wiki/Green_vegetable" title="Green vegetable" class="mw-redirect">green vegetable</a> in salads. Chickpea flour is also used to make "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Burmese_tofu&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Burmese tofu (page does not exist)">Burmese tofu</a>" which was first known among the <a href="/wiki/Shan_people" title="Shan people">Shan</a> people of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Myanmar&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Myanmar (page does not exist)">Burma</a>. The flour is used as a batter to coat various vegetables and meats before frying, such as with <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Panelle&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Panelle (page does not exist)">panelle</a></i>, a chickpea <a href="/wiki/Fritter" title="Fritter">fritter</a> from <a href="/wiki/Sicily" title="Sicily">Sicily</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-14" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-14">[14]</a></sup> Chickpea flour is also used to make the Mediterranean flatbread <a href="/wiki/Socca" title="Socca" class="mw-redirect">socca</a>, and a patty called <i>panisse</i> in Provence, southern France, made of cooked chickpea flour, poured into saucers, allowed to set, cut in strips, and fried in olive oil, often eaten during Lent.
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Halua_of_Chickpeas.jpg" title="File:Halua of Chickpeas.jpg">File:Halua of Chickpeas.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/Halva" title="Halva">Halua</a> of chickpeas, a popular sweet dish of <a href="/wiki/Bangladesh" title="Bangladesh">Bangladesh</a></div></div></div>
<p>In the Philippines, garbanzo beans preserved in syrup are eaten as sweets and in desserts such as <a href="/wiki/Halo-halo" title="Halo-halo">halo-halo</a>. <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ashkenazi&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Ashkenazi (page does not exist)">Ashkenazi</a> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Jews&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Jews (page does not exist)">Jews</a> traditionally serve whole chickpeas at a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Shalom_Zachar&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Shalom Zachar (page does not exist)">Shalom Zachar</a> celebration for baby boys.<sup id="cite_ref-15" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-15">[15]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Guasanas&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Guasanas (page does not exist)">Guasanas</a> is a Mexican chickpea recipe in which the beans are cooked in water and salt.<sup id="cite_ref-16" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-16">[16]</a></sup>
</p><p>Dried chickpeas need a long cooking time (1–2 hours) but will easily fall apart when cooked longer. If soaked for 12–24 hours before use, cooking time can be shortened by around 30 minutes. To make smooth <a href="/wiki/Hummus" title="Hummus">hummus</a> the cooked chickpeas must be processed while quite hot, since the skins disintegrate only when hot.
</p><p>Chickpeas (<i>Cicer arietinum</i>) do not cause <a href="/wiki/Lathyrism" title="Lathyrism">lathyrism</a>. Similarly named "chickling peas" (<i><a href="/wiki/Lathyrus_sativus" title="Lathyrus sativus">Lathyrus sativus</a></i>) and other plants of the genus <a href="/wiki/Lathyrus" title="Lathyrus">Lathyrus</a> contain the toxins associated with lathyrism.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Other">Other</span></h3>
<p>Because of their high protein content, chick peas are increasingly used as animal feed. {{ safesubst:#invoke:Unsubst||$N=Citation needed |date=__DATE__ |$B=
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Fix&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Fix (page does not exist)">Template:Fix</a>
}}
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Production">Production</span></h2>
<p>Chickpeas are grown in the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mediterranean_Basin&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Mediterranean Basin (page does not exist)">Mediterranean</a>, western <a href="/wiki/Asia" title="Asia">Asia</a>, the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Indian_subcontinent&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Indian subcontinent (page does not exist)">Indian subcontinent</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Australia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Australia (page does not exist)">Australia</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Palouse" title="Palouse">Palouse</a> region, and the <a href="/wiki/Great_Plains" title="Great Plains">Great Plains</a>.
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Cicer_arietinum_HabitusFruits_BotGardBln0906a.jpg" title="File:Cicer arietinum HabitusFruits BotGardBln0906a.jpg">File:Cicer arietinum HabitusFruits BotGardBln0906a.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Flowering and fruting chickpea plant</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:2005chickpea.PNG" title="File:2005chickpea.PNG">File:2005chickpea.PNG</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Chickpea output in 2005</div></div></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/India" title="India">India</a> is the world leader in chickpea (Bengal gram) production followed by <a href="/w/index.php?title=Australia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Australia (page does not exist)">Australia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Pakistan" title="Pakistan">Pakistan</a>.
</p>
<table class="sortable wikitable">
<caption> Top Chickpea Producing Countries <br />(in metric tonnes)
</caption>
<tr>
<th>Rank
</th>
<th>Country
</th>
<th>2010
</th>
<th>2011
</th></tr>
<tr>
<td> 1 </td>

<td> 290,243

<td> 131,895 </td>
<td> 72,143
</td></tr>
<tr bgcolor="#CCCCCC">

<td> 10,897,040 </td>
<td> 11,497,054
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td colspan="4"> <i>Source: <a href="/w/index.php?title=FAO&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="FAO (page does not exist)">UN Food &amp; Agriculture Organization</a></i> <sup id="cite_ref-17" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-17">[17]</a></sup>
</td></tr></table>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Nutrition">Nutrition</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Nutritionalvalue&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Nutritionalvalue (page does not exist)">Template:Nutritionalvalue</a>
Chickpeas are an excellent source of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Essential_nutrients&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Essential nutrients (page does not exist)">essential nutrients</a>, <a href="/wiki/Iron" title="Iron">iron</a>, <a href="/wiki/Folate" title="Folate" class="mw-redirect">folate</a>, <a href="/wiki/Phosphorus" title="Phosphorus">phosphorus</a>, <a href="/wiki/Protein" title="Protein">protein</a> and <a href="/wiki/Dietary_fiber" title="Dietary fiber">dietary fiber</a> (<a href="/w/index.php?title=USDA&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="USDA (page does not exist)">USDA</a> nutrient table). Chickpeas are low in fat and most of this is <a href="/wiki/Polyunsaturated_fat" title="Polyunsaturated fat">polyunsaturated</a>.
The nutrient profile of the smaller variety appears to be different, especially for fiber content which is higher than in the larger light colored variety.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Cn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Cn (page does not exist)">Template:Cn</a>
</p><p>One hundred grams of mature boiled chickpeas contain 164 calories, 2.6&#160;grams of fat (of which only 0.27&#160;grams is saturated), 7.6&#160;grams of dietary fiber and 8.9&#160;grams of protein. Chickpeas also provide several essential nutrients in moderate amounts of 10-19% of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Daily_Value&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Daily Value (page does not exist)">Daily Value</a> (table).<sup id="cite_ref-18" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-18">[18]</a></sup>
</p><p>Possibly resulting from this nutrient richness, preliminary research has shown that chickpea consumption may lower <a href="/w/index.php?title=Blood_cholesterol&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Blood cholesterol (page does not exist)">blood cholesterol</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-19" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-19">[19]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-mayo_20-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-mayo-20">[20]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="See_also">See also</span></h2>
<ul>
<li> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Extremaduran_cuisine&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Extremaduran cuisine (page does not exist)">Extremaduran cuisine</a>
</li>
<li> <a href="/wiki/Hummus" title="Hummus">Hummus</a>
</li>
</ul>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="References_and_notes">References and notes</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Reflist&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Reflist (page does not exist)">Template:Reflist</a>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="External_links">External links</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sister&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sister (page does not exist)">Template:Sister</a>
</p>
<ul>
<li> <a rel="nofollow" class="external autonumber" href="http://exploreit.icrisat.org/page/chickpea/685/60">[1]</a> Chickpea, <a href="/wiki/ICRISAT" title="ICRISAT" class="mw-redirect">ICRISAT</a>
</li>
<li> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.cai-sa.pt/graodebico.en.html">History and nutrition of chickpeas</a>, Casa Angola Internacional, Portugal (commercial site, in English), cai-sa.pt
</li>
<li> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://library2.usask.ca/theses/available/etd-03022005-153357/unrestricted/NalainiThesis.pdf">Heat and mass transfer during cooking of chickpeas (PDF)</a>
</li>
</ul>
<p><br /><strong class="error mw-ext-cite-error">Cite error: <code>&lt;ref&gt;</code> tags exist, but no <code>&lt;references/&gt;</code> tag was found</strong>
</p>

	<ul>

					<div id="p-namespaces" role="navigation" class="vectorTabs" aria-labelledby="p-namespaces-label">
	<h3 id="p-namespaces-label">Namespaces</h3>
